p.seg: Kong Rong [153-208],
The literary men of this day are
Chen Lin [d. 217], called Kongzhang, of Kuang-ling;
Wang Can [177-217], called Zhongxuan, of Shangyang;
Xu Gan [170-217], called Weichang, of Peihai;
Ruan Yu [ca 165-212], called Yuanyu, of Chenliu;
Ying Chang [d. 217], called Delian, of Runan;
and Liu Zhen [d. 217], called Gonggan, of Dongping.
These seven masters
have omitted nothing in their learning,
have no borrowed collors in their diction.
Yet they have found it most difficult to all gallop together a thousand leagues,
side by side with equal pace on their mighty steeds,
and thus to pay one another due respect.
A superior person examines himself to measure others;
and thus he is able to avoid such entanglements [e.g. envy and blindness to the worth of others].
Thus I have written a discourse on literature.
Wang Can excels in poetic expositions;
even though Xu Gan at times shows languid qi,
still he is Wang Can's match.
works like "Beginning of the Journey," "Climbing a Tower," "The Locust Tree," or "Thoughts on Travel"
or works like Xu Gan's "The Black Gibbon," "The Syphon," "The Circular Fan," or "The Orange Tree."
Yet their other writings
are no match for these.
In regard to memorials, letters and records
those of Chen Lin and Ruan Yu are preeminent in the present.
Ying Chang is agreeable but lacks vigor.
Liu Chen is vigorous but holds nothing concealed [mi; i.e. in reserve].
Kong Rong's form and qi are lofty an subtle
with something in them that surpasses all the others;
but he cannot sustain an argument,
and the principle in his work is not up to the diction.
to the point that he mixes his writing with playfulness and spoofing.
At his best
he rivals Yang Xiong [53BC-AD. 18] and Ban Gu.
Ordinary people value what is far away and feel contempt for what is close at hand.
They favor repute and turn their backs on substance.
Moreover, the suffer the ill consequences of ignorance in self-awareness,
claiming to be men of great worth.
Literature
is the same at the root, but differs in its branches [mo, a "branch tip," the later stages of a process].
Generally speaking, memorials and disquisitions should have dignity;
letters and memorials should be based on natural principle;
inscriptions and eulogy value the facts;
poetry and poetic exposition aspire to beauty.
Each of these four categories is different,
so that a writer's ability will favor some over others.
Only a comprehensive talent can achieve the full complement of these forms.
In literature qi is the dominant factor.
Qi has its normative forms - clear and murky. [For the expression the tonalities of qi there is style.???CH]
It is not to be brought by force.
Compare it to music:
though melodies be equal
and though the rhythms follow the rules,
when it comes to an inequality in drawing on a reserve of qi,
we have grounds to distinguish skill and clumsiness.
Although it may reside in a rather,
he cannot transfer it to his son; nor can an elder brother transfer it to the younger.
I would say that literary works are the supreme achievement in the business of state,
a splendor that does not decay.
A time will come when a person's life ends
glory and pleasure go no further than this body.
To carry both to eternity,
there is nothing to compare with the unending permanence of the literary work.
So writers of ancient times
entrusted their persons to ink and the brush
and let their thoughts be seen in their compositions;
depending neither on a good historian
nor on momentum from a powerful patron,
their reputations were handed down to posterity on their own force.
The Earl of the West [later made King Wen of the Zhou], when imprisoned, amplified the Book of Changes;
the Duke of Zhou, though in his glory, prescribed the Rites.
The former did not ignore this [the importance of literary work] in spite of hardship;
the latter was not distracted by health and pleasure.
From this we can see
how the ancients thought nothing of large jade disks [marks of wealth], but valued each moment,
fearful lest their time pass them [read 己CH] by.
Yet people usually do not exert themselves:
in poverty and low station they fear the hunger and cold;
amid wealth and honour they drift with the distractions of pleasure.
They busy themselves with the demands of what lies right before their eyes,
and neglect an accomplishment lasting a thousand years.
Overhead, the days and months pass away from us;
here below, face and body waste away.
Suddenly we will move off into transformation with all the other things of the world-
this is the greatest pain for a person with high aspirations.
Kong Rong and the others have already passed away,
and only the discourses composed by Xu Gan
are the fully realized work of an individual writer.
writing in a letter to his elder brother Ban Zhao [33-108]:
"Wuzhong [Fu Yi] became Imperal Librarian through his facility in composition:
whenever he used his writing brush, he couldn't stop himself."
People are good at [or fond of] making themselves known;
but since literature is not of one form along
few can be good at everything.
Thus each person disparages that in which he is weak
by the criterion of those things in which he is strong.
There is a village saying:
"The worn-out broom that belongs to my household
is worth a thousand in gold."
Such is the ill consequence of a lack of self-awareness.

At break of day my heart is still unquiet,
I dress myself, then stand there hesitating.
I hesitate, not knowing where I should go -
A recluse may dwell in a secluded valley.
In the morning he culls crss in the suthern gorge,
At night he rests at the foot of the western hill.
Light branches lace above him like the clouds,
Thick foliage forms a tent of kingfisher-green.
Eddying winds linger in the grove of magnolias,
Their fragrance swirls to meet the graceful trees.
The pleasant plashing of the mountain burn (!)
Mournful music wells from these magic waters,
Their mournful echoes echo in the coigns of the crags
Their falling notes echo in coigns of the crags,
Such perfect joy can simply not be feigned,
Why harm the Primal Unity with meddling?
If wealth and renown are difficult to obtain,
better halt my carriage and do what I want to do.
